subject: Re: [junit] Some questions about JUnit 4
msgSnippet: #: by Elliotte Harold s words the mind was *winged* :# ... Short answer is: no. JUnit is known for the fact that you cannot order the way your methods will be
messageBody:
#: by Elliotte Harold's words the mind was *winged* :#
> I've been experimenting with JUnit 4 and mostly I like it. I do have a
> few questions:
>
> 1. If there are multiple @Before annotated methods in a class, are any
> guarantees made about what order they are invoked in? Same question for
> @After, @BeforeClass, and @AfterClass.

Short answer is: no. JUnit is known for the fact that you cannot order the way your methods will be
invoked.

TestNG is offering a logical ordering through dependency definitions (dependsOnGroups and
dependsOnMethods that can be used on both configuration methods (JUnit name for them is @Before,
@After, etc) and for test methods.

>
> 2. Is there any way to control the order in which tests are run? Or is
> that pretty much still up to the test runner like in JUnit 3?
>

same as above.

> 3. Is there any equivalent to the suite() method in JUnit 3? i.e. how do
> I bundle up several different test classes so they can be run as a group?
>

don't know. i would like to find out.

> 4. Java 5 is obviously required to build JUnit 4. Can it nonetheless run
> in Java 1.4? or is Java 5 pretty much required for anything that uses
> JUnit 4?
>

It cannot run on any JDK prior to 1.5 because it is based only on annotations. You can take a look
at TestNG which instead is able to run in both 1.5 and prior 1.5

> 5. The GUI test runners don't appear to be in Version4 CVS. Will they
> return at some point?
>

afaik no.

> 6. Why are Assert.failSame, Assert.failNotSame, Assert.failNotEquals(),
> and Assert.format now public?
>
> Any light anyone can shed on these questions would be appreciated. Thanks!
>
i can see why failSame, failNotSame and failNotEquals can be public. You may use them. Not sure
about format.

cheers,
